entry.title: Armenia finalizes dissolution of scandal-ridden investment fund: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS

media:group.media:title: Armenia finalizes dissolution of scandal-ridden investment fund: THIS WEEK IN BUSINESS
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia‚Äôs Central Bank approved the sale of HSBC‚Äôs local subsidiary to the country‚Äôs biggest bank, putting an end to the financial giant‚Äôs nearly 30-year presence in Armenia. üìç The Armenian government again pushed back plans to take a minority stake in the long-stalled Amulsar gold mine project. That has now been delayed to November 1. üìç The government finalized the dissolution of ANIF, the scandal-ridden, state-owned investment fund that collapsed this year amid mounting allegations of mismanagement. üìç S&P affirmed Armenia‚Äôs ‚ÄúBB-/B‚Äù sovereign credit ratings with a ‚Äústable outlook.‚Äù

entry.title: Armenia formalizes border commission with Azerbaijan

media:group.media:title: Armenia formalizes border commission with Azerbaijan
media:group.media:description:
üìç Baku and Yerevan formalized the guidelines for the activities of their previously ad hoc joint border delimitation and demarcation commissions, Armenia‚Äôs Foreign Ministry said. üìç Azerbaijan seriously hindered international humanitarian efforts during its more than nine-month blockade of Nagorno-Karabakh last year, a new investigation by the Organized Crime and Corruption Reporting Project found.

media:group.media:title: ‚ÄòRussian History‚Äô by Dominic Lieven
media:group.media:description:
Historian Dominic Lieven delivers a lecture on Russian history at a symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The lecture took place on July 4 in Yerevan.
Dominic Lieven is a distinguished British historian and professor specializing in Russian and international history. He is currently a senior research fellow at Trinity College, Cambridge, and a fellow of the British Academy. His research focuses on the Russian Empire, the Napoleonic Wars, and the First World War. He has authored several notable books, including ‚ÄúRussia Against Napoleon‚Äù and "Towards the Flame: Empire, War and the End of Tsarist Russia."
This year‚Äôs Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Yerevan, Tbilisi, and Istanbul from July 1 to July 20.

entry.title: Armenia to hold constitutional referendum in 2027

media:group.media:title: Armenia to hold constitutional referendum in 2027
media:group.media:description:
üìç Armenia will hold a constitutional referendum in 2027, the country‚Äôs justice minister said. üìç An independent watchdog found that Armenian Public Television violated journalistic norms by falsely claiming protesters were paid to join anti-government demonstrations. üìç On patrol with the EU on the Armenia-Azerbaijan border: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Tg5vf9_2Kuc üìç Armenian Americans and the U.S. presidential elections: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Uh19NNHRjb0

entry.title: Why aren‚Äôt Armenian Americans as politically influential as they should be?

media:group.media:title: Why aren‚Äôt Armenian Americans as politically influential as they should be?
media:group.media:description:
CivilNet commentator and political consultant Eric Hacopian sits down with CivilNet‚Äôs Mark Dovich to discuss why Armenian Americans are not as influential in U.S. politics as they could and should be ‚Äî and what to do about it. They also take a look at the current state of the presidential race between Democratic candidate Kamala Harris and Republican candidate Donald Trump.
00:00 What‚Äôs the state of politics in the Armenian American community? 2:05 What are Armenian Americans rallying around? 6:35 Are candidates reaching out to Armenian American voters? 9:56 Why did Armenia‚Äôs ambassador go to the party conventions? 10:57 Why is the election still a 50-50 toss-up?

entry.title: Azerbaijan‚Äôs top diplomat warns Armenia‚Äôs ‚Äòmilitarization‚Äô threatens normalization talks

media:group.media:title: Azerbaijan‚Äôs top diplomat warns Armenia‚Äôs ‚Äòmilitarization‚Äô threatens normalization talks
media:group.media:description:
üìç Senior Azerbaijani officials reiterated that signing a normalization deal hinges on Armenia removing indirect references to Nagorno-Karabakh from its constitution and called Armenia‚Äôs ‚Äòmass militarization‚Äô a major threat to the process. üìç Russian President Vladimir Putin called Azerbaijani President Ilham Aliyev to review the state of ongoing efforts to reach a normalization deal. üìç Opposition leader Bagrat Galstanyan confirmed he is planning to resume protests against Prime Minister Nikol Pashinyan next month. üìç An appeals court shortened the detention period of former government minister and Pashinyan critic Armen Ashotyan, raising expectations he may be released imminently.
#CivilNet #’ç’´’æ’´’¨’Ü’•’© #dailyarmenia

entry.title: The Russian Revolution and the Making of a Self-Denying Empire

media:group.media:title: The Russian Revolution and the Making of a Self-Denying Empire
media:group.media:description:
Historians Sheila Fitzpatrick and Ronald Grigor Suny deliver a lecture on class and nationality in the Russian Empire at a symposium organized by the Monterey Initiative in Russian Studies at the Middlebury Institute of International Studies at Monterey. The lecture took place on July 1 in Yerevan.
Sheila Fitzpatrick is an Australian historian renowned for her expertise on Soviet and modern Russian history, particularly during Joseph Stalin‚Äôs rule.
Ronald Grigor Suny is a distinguished professor of history at the University of Michigan and emeritus professor of political science and history at the University of Chicago This year‚Äôs Monterey Summer Symposium on Russia took place in Yerevan, Tbilisi, and Istanbul from July 1 to July 20.
